For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions about the element <math alttext="S i" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Si</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and some of its compounds.

(a) The mass spectrum of a pure sample of <math alttext="S i" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Si</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown below.

(i) How many protons and how many neutrons are in the nucleus of an atom of the most abundant isotope of <math alttext="S i" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>i</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?
(ii) Write the ground-state electron configuration of <math alttext="S i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Si</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Two compounds that contain <math alttext="S i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Si</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="S i O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SiO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="S i H 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Si</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(b) At <math alttext="161 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>161</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S i H 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Si</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> boils but <math alttext="S i O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SiO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> remains as a solid. Using principles of interparticle forces, explain the difference in boiling points.

At high temperatures, <math alttext="S i H 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SiH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> decomposes to form solid silicon and hydrogen gas.
(c) Write a balanced equation for the reaction.

A table of absolute entropies of some substances is given below.

Substance
 <math alttext="S naught, in joules per mole kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>°</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mo>(</mo><mtext>J</mtext><mo>/</mo><mo>(</mo><mtext>mol</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>K)</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="S i, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Si</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="18" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="S i H 4, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SiH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

(d) Explain why the absolute molar entropy of <math alttext="S i, solid" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Si</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> is less than that of <math alttext="H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) Calculate the value, in <math alttext="joules per mole kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>J/</mtext><mfenced><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext><mo>·</mo><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mfenced></math>, of <math alttext="delta S naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>S</mi><mo>°</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> for the reaction.
(f) The reaction is thermodynamically favorable at all temperatures. Explain why the reaction occurs only at high temperatures.

(g) A partial photoelectron spectrum of pure <math alttext="S i" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Si</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown below. On the spectrum, draw the missing peak that corresponds to the electrons in the <math alttext="3 p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> sublevel.

(h) Using principles of atomic structure, explain why the first ionization energy of <math alttext="G e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ge</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is lower than that of <math alttext="S i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Si</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(i) A single photon with a wavelength of <math alttext="4.00 times 10 to the negative 7 power, meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.00</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is absorbed by the <math alttext="S i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Si</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample. Calculate the energy of the photon in joules.
